case_name: Civil Appeals No. 1026 to 1031, 902 to 905 of 1963

facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 1026 to 1031, 902 to 905 of 1963 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION, -Civil Appeals No. 1026 to 1031, 902 to 905 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated 21st August, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated 21st August, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions

facts.text: On June 6, 1957, Central Government issued notification under s. 3(3A) of Essential Commodities Act, 1955 for price control of rice and paddy in Andhra Pradesh for three months.

anchor.surface_text: On June 6, 1957, a numberification was issued by the Central Government under s. 3 3A  of the Essential Commodities Act, No. 10 of 1955,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: On July 31, 1957, Central Government delegated powers under s.3 to Shri K. S. Krishnan, Deputy Director Food, Vijayawada, for rice and paddy in Andhra Pradesh for three months.

anchor.surface_text: On July 31, 1957, the Central Government made another numberification directing that the powers companyferred on it by s. 3 of the Act to make orders providing for the matters specified in cl.  f

facts.text: On July 31, 1957, Central Government authorised Shri K.S. Krishnan to determine average market rate of rice and paddy in Andhra Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Further on the same day the Central Government issued another numberification by which in pursuance of cl. of sub-s.  3A  of s. 3 of the Act, the Central Government authorised the said Shri

facts.text: On August 20, 1957, Shri Krishnan directed rice millers in Tadepalligudem to sell rice to Assistant Director Food at price per s.3(3A).

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1957, Shri Krishnan in exercise of the powers companyferred upon him by the numberifications mentioned above directed a number of rice millers in Tadepalligudem to sell

facts.text: Rice was delivered to Assistant Director Food up to September 13, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of this order, such quantities of rice as were ordered to be sold were delivered to the Assistant Director  Food  on various dates upto September 13, 1957.

facts.text: Prices for rice procured under August 20, 1957 orders fixed in September 1957; appellants dispute proper fixation under Act.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that prices are claimed to have been fixed by Shri Krishnan for the rice procured under the orders passed on August 20, 1957 and on subsequent dates in accordance

facts.text: On September 14, 1957, Central Government fixed maximum price for rice/paddy >10 maunds in Krishna, West Godavari, East Godavari districts.

anchor.surface_text: On September 14, 1957, the Central Government issued a numberification fixing the, maximum price at which rice and paddy of various kinds was to be sold in any one transaction

facts.text: Deputy Director made requisitions of rice from appellants between September 14, 1957 and December 29, 1957 at maximum prices fixed.

anchor.surface_text: Following this fixation the Deputy Director made requisitions between September 14, 1957 and December 29, 1957 of different varieties of rice from various appellants under the powers

facts.text: On December 30, 1957, Central Government refixed lower maximum prices in Krishna, West Godavari, East Godavari, Guntur districts.

anchor.surface_text: On December 30, 1957, after the new rice crop had companye into the market, the Central Government issued another numberification by which maximum prices were refixed in the districts

facts.text: Procurement of rice by Deputy Director after December 30, 1957 at reduced maximum prices.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter there was more pro- curement of rice by the Deputy Director  food  from the various appellants and he claims to have fixed prices therefore

facts.text: Appellants filed writ petitions in High Court challenging price fixations and notifications.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants therefore along with a large number of other rice millers filed writ petitions before the High Court.

facts.text: High Court rejected appellants' contentions and dismissed writ petitions with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected all the companytentions raised on behalf of the, appellants and dismissed the writ petitions with companyts.

facts.text: High Court granted certificates for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for and obtained certificates from the High Court and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Deputy Director used Vijayawada published prices (80 miles from Tadepalligudem) for average market rate as no nearer published figures available.

anchor.surface_text: Now what the Deputy Director did was to take into account the rates published in Vijavawada, which it is said is At a distance of 80 miles from Tadepellagudem.

facts.text: Deputy Director adjusted Vijayawada prices for transport and quality (inferior rice).

anchor.surface_text: What he did was to take into account the published figures of Vijayawada and then make adjustments taking into account the transport charges and the quality of rice procured,

facts.text: Nallarlu and Garikulu rice procured from appellants slightly inferior to Akkulu rice used for Vijayawada prices.

anchor.surface_text: for in two cases the rice procured by him was number quoted in the figures available in Vijayawada. It, however, appears that these two varieties of rice procured are slightly inferior

facts.text: Prices at Tadepalligudem generally lower than Vijayawada by about Rs. 1.20 per rates compiled by State Marketing Officer.

anchor.surface_text: These rates were companypiled before the numberification of June 6, 1957 in a free market and show that there is a difference in price between Tadepallegudem and Vijayawada

facts.text: New rice crop came into market from November 1957, leading to price reduction on Dec 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Now the reason for reduction of prices on December 30 was that the new crop came into the market from November 1957.

concepts.interpretation: Applies when no controlled price fixed; sub-cl. (a) and (b) only where controlled price exists; sub-cl. (c) uses average market rate from published figures in locality or neighbouring; published figures mean publicly available like newspapers, not private accounts; determination final, limited judicial review under Art.226 only for serious injustice.

anchor.surface_text: The next attack on the orders passed under the Act is that they violate Art. 14 of the Constitution inasmuch as they relate only to certain districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh and not to others.

concepts.interpretation: Classification valid as orders confined to surplus rice producing districts which form a class by themselves; serves purpose of price control under s.3(1) ECA and stabilizes prices statewide.

It was unnecessary to apply the orders to other districts for the control of price in those districts would economically result in stabilising prices in other districts of the State also. These districts therefore obviously form a class by themselves

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is based on Art. 31 2 . That article provides that no property shall be compulsorily acquired or requisitioned save for a public purpose and save by authority of a law which provides for compensation for the property so acquired or requisitioned and either fixes the amount of the compensation or specifies the principles on which, and the manner in which, the compensation is to be determined and given.

issues.text: Do the provisions of ss. 3 and 4 of the Essential Commodities Act impose unreasonable restrictions on the rights under Art. 19(1)(f) and (g)?

anchor.surface_text: We shall first take up the contention based on cls.  f  and  g  of Art. 19 1 . It is said that the provisions of the Act impose unreasonable restrictions on the right to acquire, hold and dispose of property, and to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation. trade or business.

issues.text: Do the orders passed under the Act violate Art. 14 of the Constitution by relating only to certain districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh?

anchor.surface_text: The next attack on the orders passed under the Act is that they violate Art. 14 of the Constitution inasmuch as they relate only to certain districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh and not to others.

issues.text: Does the Essential Commodities Act comply with Art. 31(2) by providing principles and manner for determining compensation?

anchor.surface_text: The next contention is based on Art. 31 2 . That article provides that no property shall be compulsorily acquired or requisitioned save for a public purpose and save by authority of a law which provides for compensation for the property so acquired or requisitioned and either fixes the amount of the compensation or specifies the principles on which, and the manner in which, the compensation is to be determined and given.

issues.text: Should procurement of rice after December 29, 1957 be at the higher prices fixed on September 14, 1957 for stocks purchased by appellants between September 14 and December 29, 1957, rather than the reduced prices of December 30, 1957?

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the contention that the procurement which was made after December 29, 1957, when the price was reduced by the notification of December 30, 1957, as compared with the price fixed in the notification dated September 14, 1957, should have been in accordance with the notification of September 14, 1957 at any rate insofar as the rice purchased by the appellants between September 14 and December 29, 1957 was concerned.

issues.text: Were the prices fixed by the Deputy Director for rice procured between August 20 and September 13, 1957 in accordance with s. 3(3A) of the Essential Commodities Act?
Do sub-clauses (a) and (b) of clause (iii) of s. 3(3A) apply even in the absence of a controlled price, requiring the officer to first attempt agreement before applying sub-clause (c)?
Do the words 'published figures' in clause (iv) of s. 3(3A) include prices in private accounts books shown to tax authorities?

anchor.surface_text: the words published figures in cl.  iv  would include even the prices in the accounts books of the appellants for these prices must be taken to be published prices inasmuch as the accounts books used to be shown to sales tax and income-tax authorities and the entries therein were therefore published.

issues.text: Was the Deputy Director's use of published figures from Vijayawada (neighbouring locality) and adjustments for transport and quality appropriate under clause (iv) of s. 3(3A)?
What is the scope of judicial review under Art. 226 given the finality clause in s. 3(3A)(iv)?

arguments.claim: finality under s.3(3A)(iv) limits Art.226 review to serious injustice cases
High Court rejected all contentions of appellants

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rejected all the contentions raised on behalf of the, appellants and dismissed the writ petitions with costs.

holdings.text: Sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 are not hit by Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, for the reasons given in Harishanker Baglascase,  1  which were accepted in Bhanamal Gulzarilals case,  2  we hold that ss. 3 and 4 of the Act are number hit by Art. 19 1   f  and  g  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upheld by binding precedents: Essential Supplies Act in Harishankar Bagla; ECA in Bhanamal Gulzarimal; sections similar.

holdings.text: The price control orders under the Act do not violate Article 14 as the districts concerned are surplus rice producing districts forming a separate class.

anchor.surface_text: The short answer to this contention is that the districts to which the orders applied are surplus rice producing districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh and that is why the orders were confined to those districts. It was unnecessary to apply the orders to other districts for the control of price in those districts Would economically result in stabilising prices in other districts of the State also.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intelligible differentia (surplus districts) has rational nexus to price stabilization objective under s.3(1) ECA.

holdings.text: The Essential Commodities Act complies with Article 31(2) as it provides principles (fair price under s.3(1)) and manner (ss.3(3), 3A) for compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 1  provides for availability of essential commodities at fair prices. So the first principle which the Act provides is that the price fixed should be fair, and that involves in it all factors which have to be taken into account in fixing a fair price... Further the manner in which the price should be fixed has also been indicated in sub-ss.  3  and  3A  of s. 3 of the Act. We are therefore of opinion that the argument based on Art. 31 2  must also fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(1) fair price principle and detailed pricing manner in s.3(3),(3A) satisfy constitutional requirements.

holdings.text: Procurement after December 30, 1957 at reduced maximum prices valid even for rice purchased by appellants between September 14 and December 29, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the contention of the appellants that rice procured by them between September 14 and December 29 should have been requisitioned at least at prices fixed by the notification of September 14 must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to free market price fall due to new crop; prevents locking higher prices, aligns with fair price objective.

holdings.text: Sub-clauses (a) and (b) of s.3(3A)(iii) apply only where a controlled price has been fixed; absent that, sub-clause (c) applies directly.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading: (a),(b) complementary, conditioned on 'if any' controlled price; here none, so (c).

holdings.text: Prices fixed by Deputy Director for rice procured August 20 to September 13, 1957 were in accordance with s.3(3A).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Used nearest published figures (Vijayawada) with proper adjustments; complies with cl.(iv); finality clause.

holdings.text: 'Published figures' under s.3(3A)(iv) means figures publicised to general public (e.g., newspapers, radio), not private account books even if shown to tax authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The words published figures must be given their ordinary meaning. That is that the figures should be publicised in some way, say, for example, in newspapers, or on the Radio or in any other manner, so that they are made known to the general public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinary meaning requires general publicity; private books not 'published'.

holdings.text: Deputy Director's use of Vijayawada published figures (nearest available, 80 miles away) with adjustments for transport and quality was appropriate under s.3(3A)(iv).

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, if the Deputy Director took into account the nearest available published figures, i.e., prices prevailing at Vijayawada, it cannot be said that he acted against the provisions of cl. iv of sub-s. 3A . What he did was to take into account the published figures of Vijayawada and then make adjustments taking into account the transport charges and the quality of rice procured

holdings.reasoning_summary: No nearer published figures; adjustments proper for distance (supported by marketing data) and inferior quality.

holdings.text: Finality clause in s.3(3A)(iv) limits High Court Art.226 review to cases of serious injustice from disregard of statutory procedure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Words indicate non-interference absent serious injustice; jurisdiction preserved but restrained.

holdings.text: 1964 notification does not invalidate 1957 price adjustments treating Nallarlu/Garikulu as inferior to Akkulu rice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 1964 doesn't override contemporaneous 1957 evidence; allows state discretion for varieties.

precedents.citation: Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1

anchor.surface_text: Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 1 while the Act was upheld in Union of India v. M s. Bhanamal Gulzarimal.  2 As a matter of fact in Bhanamal Gulzarimals case 2 ss. 3 and 4 of the Act were number specifically challenged on account of the earlier deci- sion

precedents.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946 do not violate Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution

precedents.citation: Union of India v. M s. Bhanamal Gulzarimal.  2

anchor.surface_text: Union of India v. M s. Bhanamal Gulzarimal.  2 As a matter of fact in Bhanamal Gulzarimals case 2 ss. 3 and 4 of the Act were number specifically challenged on account of the earlier deci- sion in Harishanker Baglas case. 3 It is therefore too late in the day for the appellants to challenge the validity of ss. 3 and 4 of the Act on the ground that they violate the fundamental rights guaranteed under Art. 19 1 f and g . As already indicated, ss. 3 and 4 of the Essential Supplies Temporary Powers Act, 1946 were in terms similar to ss. 3 and4 of the Act and were upheld by this Court in Harishankar Bagla scase. 1 Therefore, for the reasons given in Harishanker Baglascase, 2 which were accepted in Bhanamal Gulzarilals case, 2 we hold that ss. 3 and 4 of the Act are number hit by Art. 19 1 f and g of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v. M/s Bhanamal Gulzarimal
precedents.cited_proposition: Sections 3 and 4 of the Essential Commodities Act do not violate Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution

edges.explanation: The holding that price control orders do not violate Article 14, as districts form a separate class, directly addresses the issue of Article 14 violation by limiting orders to certain districts.

anchor.surface_text: The short answer to this contention is that the districts to which the orders applied are surplus rice producing districts in the State of Andhra Pradesh and that is why the orders were confined to those districts. It was unnecessary to apply the orders to other districts for the control of price in those districts Would economically result in stabilising prices in other districts of the State also.

The High Court rejected all the contentions raised on behalf of the, appellants and dismissed the writ petitions with costs. The appellants then applied for and obtained certificates from the High Court and that is how the matter has come up before us.

Section 3 1  provides for availability of essential commodities at fair prices. So the first principle which the Act provides is that the price fixed should be fair, and that involves in it all factors which have to be taken into account in fixing a fair price... Further the manner in which the price should be fixed has also been indicated in sub-ss.  3  and  3A  of s. 3 of the Act. We are therefore of opinion that the argument based on Art. 31 2  must also fail.

The High Court rejected all the contentions raised on behalf of the, appellants and dismissed the writ petitions with costs. The appellants then applied for and obtained certificates from the High Court and that is how the matter has come up before us.
